messages.content: 9-1-1, what's your emergency?
Cushing Police Department. We've got a little boy missing. Have you had any reports on one?
No, ma'am. We haven't. How old is he?
Four.
Okay, what's your address?
722 East 3rd.
Do you know what he was wearing?
No, I don't. His mother does. This is his grandmother.
Okay. What color is his hair?
It's brown. Brown hair, blue eyes. He's autistic and can't talk.
Okay, who am I speaking to?
Tom Pennington.
Who's his mother?
Cheryl Ryan Pennington.
Ryan Pennington?
Yes, they were asleep in the living room. He's autistic and doesn't sleep regular patterns, so he was up all night. They needed some sleep.
Okay. Have you checked all the closets, under the beds, and other places?
I don't know. They just woke up.
Is his mom out looking for him?
Yes.
What's his name?
Blake.
Okay. Does she have a cell phone?
Yes, but I don't know her number.
Okay, you have 722 East 3rd, an autistic 4-year-old boy with no clothing description at this time. I'm trying to get more information.
Yes, Connie Pennington's the grandmother.
Okay. Has she found him?
No.
Connie, do you know how long he's been gone?
No. Still haven't found him.
Okay. Is that Ryan? Let me talk to Ryan right quick, Connie.
She's hysterical.
Okay. Were the doors unlocked?
I don't know. Let me talk to Ryan.
Connie, let me talk to Ryan.
She's gone down the hall.
Ask her to look in all the closets and under the bed. Also, ask her if she knows what he was wearing.
What was he wearing? Connie, I need to talk to Ryan. We're wasting valuable time with her acting like this.
She needs to talk to you, Ryan.
Sure.
Did she leave again?
Yes. She's refusing to talk to me to provide any further information. Still no clothing description at this time. Brown hair, blue eyes, name of Blake.
Okay. We are dispatching help to 722 East 3rd.
